titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mrs: Adams and my brother went to Charlottenburg this afternoon.— At the Casino— Finished the volume I have of Rudolph von Werdenberg: the last pages are missing— T’is an easy writer, and a pretty novel.

2. My brother dined at Charlottenburg.— Ride with Mrs: A— and at the Casino.— Began reading Meissner’s Alcibiades.— The object of the writer is to paint the Grecian hero, as a boy, as a youth, and as a grown man until his death—principally in dialogues.— Brydone in the Evening— Several letters.
3. At the play this Evening. The performance—“Leichter Sinn”—Levity—a Comedy by Iffland.— Pretty well pleased with it, though I understood not much of it.
4. Very bad cold— At the Casino this afternoon. Finished the first volume of Meissners Alcibiades.— The study of German now absorbs the greatest part of my time.

5.— Cold continues very bad.— Postponed reading the remaining volumes of the Alcibiades, and began Hermana von Unna, a novel relating to the secret tribunal of Westphalia— Spent almost the whole day in reading it.— At the Casino in the afternoon.
6. Doctor Brown called this morning. Is going to England the day after to-morrow. Mr: Engeström in the afternoon—conversation upon business.— Casino— Letters from America.

7. Called this morning upon Baron Alvensleben, and Mr: Struensee to deliver the Letters from Mr: Poleske.— Struensee was not at home.— Conversation with Alvensleben.— In the Evening at Dr: Brown’s, and gave him a letter for Mr: King.
8. At Schicklers this forenoon— Mr: Garlike called and passed an hour with us in the Evening. Dr: Brown went off this morning at about 8.
9. Usual Sunday morning occupation, and walk in the Park— Reading the Papers which Mr: Garlike lent me. At the Casino in the Evening, at a dull though necessary pastime.

10. Mr: Richards dined with us. At the Princess Henry’s evening party— The Duke and Duchess of Sudermania were there— They are going to Carlsbad.— The Duke has left Sweden, probably because since the end of his regency, he has many reasons for dissatisfaction.— Played Boston, with Messrs: Knoblauch, Helbig and Sievers.

11. Finished reading Hermann von Unna—a novel comprehending the adventures of too many persons, and consisting too much in relation, too little in action— Hermann is not the most conspicuous personage of the work, and the writer often loses sight of him for 60, 70 and even 100 pages together.— Read part of Iffland’s Reise nach der Stadt.— a play which we saw performed not long since.

12. Finished Iffland’s play, and read a few pages in the second volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades— Dined with Mrs: Brown at Charlottenburg— Mrs: and Miss Bischoffswerder dined there likewise— Returned home early in the Evening. Began to read a life of Lessing, taken from the circulating library—written by that author’s brother.

13. In reading the life of Lessing this day, I met with an anecdote, of which the application was inevitable— Lessing and his friend Mylius at a certain period undertook to learn the Spanish language. They had made some progress, and by way of practicing, were speaking it one day as they were walking under the Linden here at Berlin— A Spaniard overheard them, and rejoyced at finding persons who as he supposed could converse with him in his own language, accosted them and attempted to talk with them, but found they could not understand or reply to a word that he said— His was the language of common life—their’s what they had gathered from books— And so it usually happens (says the biographer) with learned men who in acquiring a language have no other teacher but themselves.— Rainy day— Miss Neale to see Mrs: Adams this afternoon.— At the Casino.
14. We attempted to go to the play this afternoon, but found the house so full that we could not get seats. Mrs: Adams went and took tea with the young Countess Neale.

15. Rained, a considerable part of the day. Mr: Richards dined with us.— Evening at the play. had Maske fur Maske, a comedy and a farce entitled the highest prize— Understood enough of them to comprehend the plot of both pieces, and some parts of the dialogue.

16. Sunday morning— Long walk in the park though it rained almost all day— Evening at Bellevue. Mrs: Adams and my brother stayed only a short time— Whist with the Minister Thulemeyer— Marquis de Musquiz and Count Wintzingerode— Finished reading the life of Lessing.

17. A sleepless and uncomfortable night— Began again in the second volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades—did scarcely any thing but read in it—felt very indolent— Miss Neale at tea in the afternoon. Read Brydone in the Eveg:

18. Went with Mrs: Adams to the review, out from the Oranienburg gate— Similar to those in the spring. The representation this day was of battle, and retreat.— A very good one— That of yesterday I missed. The greatest are to be at Potsdam, the last days of the week— Wrote Mr Murray— At the Casino—finished this Evening Brydone’s tour through Sicily and Malta— Began Shakespear Henry 5. as the Evenings grow longer we shall resume this reading which we dropped as the summer advanced.
19. Miss Neale here this afternoon: is going into the Country.— At the Casino this Evening. But found no french papers. Read a couple of Acts—of Henry 5.

20. Finished the second volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades and began upon the third— I doubt the goodness of these historical novels, where half is founded upon records and half fiction— It obscures the truth of real history— Mrs: Adams suffered very much with the tooth ache— Had it drawn at length— Casino before dinner— Continued Henry 5. in the Evening.

21. Letter to Messrs: Krochman & Jacobsen at Lisbon— To Mr: King— Walk in the park. Met Mr: Garlike, who had news of the surrender of the french in Ireland.— Finished reading Henry 5. and began upon the first part of Henry 6.—which is a very dull thing.

22. Mr: Richards called this morning with information of the defeat of the french fleet near Rosetta— To be confirmed— At the play in the Evening— “die entfuhrung”—a comedy by Jünger; and der Schwarze Mann, a farce from the french, but very dull— From the specimens I have seen hitherto, I cannot say much for the german theatre—read two acts of Henry 6. first part.
23. Finished the third volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades.— Sunday morning— Walk in the park.— My brother dined at Charlottenburg.— Rode out with Mrs: A, in the evening at the Casino.

24. Mr: Richards dined with us.— Count Finckenstein paid a visit this afternoon to Mrs: Adams— Mr: Garlike called on us.— Evening at Princess Henry’s— Late there— Company not large. Whist with Madame de Blumenthal, Count Carmer, and GeneralBegan this morning on the 4th: volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades.
25. Somewhat unwell— Wrote to Mr: Murray.— Letter from Mr: Garlike with a turkish proclamation. Mrs: Brown to visit Mrs: Adams.

26. Visit this afternoon from the Baron de Hagen.— Evening at Bellevue— Whist with Madame de Heinitz, M. de Sydow, and M. de Rothenburgh. Conversation afterwards with Count Schmettau.— Did not stay to supper.— Weather at length getting better.

27. Dined with Mrs: Brown at Charlottenburg— Mr: Garlike and Mr: Foster there— Mr: Dorna called in the afternoon.— Mr: Richards came home with us this Evening.— Finished reading the 4th: and last volume of Meissner’s Alcibiades.

28.— Began this morning to read Lessing’s works.— Read his epigrams, which are not very brilliant, and the beginning of his Essay upon the nature and character of the Epigram. This reading is more difficult than that of ordinary novels.— Mr: Welsh arrived this afternoon, to serve as my secretary, instead of my brother, who is upon his return home.

29. Very busily employed all day.— Mr: Richards dined with us.— Went with me after dinner to a notary, Mr: Lettow, who acknowledged my power of Attorney to my brother.— Mr: Garlike called in the Evening to take leave of my brother.

30. My brother went off this morning at five o’clock;—to Dessau— Intending to proceed from thence to Hamburg, and as soon as possible, to America— It is something more than four years, since we sailed from Boston together, and we have continued together the principal part of this time. He has ever been a faithful friend, and kind companion, as well as an industrious and valuable assistant to me.— In compliance with my repeated requests, he has prolonged his stay in Europe, much beyond his original intention, and now it is with an heavy heart that I part with him.— Morning spent in the customary Sunday’s employment.— Rode in the afternoon with Mrs: Adams— Evening a short time at the Casino— Weather very fine all day.

Day. Rise between seven and eight— Two or three hours of German. Breakfast.— Write two or three hours more. Walk— Dinner at 3.— Afternoon read German again an hour— At the Casino— Reading a couple of hours in the Evening to Mrs: Adams— Sup between 9 & 10— Bed an hour later.— I have made some progress this month in my German: but still find great difficulties recur, the instant I quit the easy path of novel-reading.— Besides which I feel a perpetual, unceasing impulse towards relaxation of my exertions—and every the least variation from my regular course of life, deprives me at least of many days of assiduous study.
